英文法規名稱: Enforcement Rules of the Overseas Chinese Identity Certification Act
中文法規名稱: 華僑身分證明條例施行細則
沿革內容:
1.Promulgated by Order of OCAC No.Chiao-Cheng-Yi-092301146911 dated March 26, 2003.
2.Amended by Order of OCAC No.Chiao-Cheng-Fu-09330340061 dated July 28,2004.

法規內容.條文內容: These Enforcement Rules are issued pursuant to Article 16 of the Overseas Chinese Identity Certification Act (hereinafter referred to as the “Act”).

“Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement” referred to in the Act means an Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement issued in respect of a passport pursuant to Article 10 of the Act and Article 33 of the Passport Act Enforcement Rules.
“Residing overseas” referred to in the Act means residing in countries or regions other than the Taiwan, Mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau regions.

The competent authority may recognize permanent residency status at the place of overseas residence, as referred to in Article 4, Paragraph 1, Subparagraph 1, Item (1) of the Act, based on a valid passport issued by the overseas place of residence, permanent residency visa, proof of nationality of the applicant, or other documentation of proof approved by the competent authority.
The competent authority is entitled to not recognize permanent residency status of the applicant where a document described in the preceding paragraph does not entitle the applicant to permanent residency at the place of overseas residence pursuant to laws and regulations of such place of overseas residence.

“Eligible for further extensions of residency” referred to in Article 4, Paragraph 1, Subparagraph 2, Item (1) and Subparagraph 3 of the Act shall be recognized in accordance with the laws and regulations of the place of overseas residence.

Only Republic of China ("ROC") nationals who currently has or previously had household registration in Taiwan region may apply for Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate pursuant to Article 4, Paragraph 1, Subparagraph 3 of the Act.

“Has lived legally overseas for ten (10) consecutive years, is legally employed at such place of overseas residence for four (4) years or more” referred to in Article 4, Paragraph 3, Subparagraph 3 of the Act shall mean that the applicant have lived legally overseas in one or more countries or regions for ten (10) consecutive years, and has been legally employed within the same place of overseas residence in the last four (4) years.

“Men who have not fulfilled his military service obligations” referred to in Article 4, Paragraph 3 and Article 10, Paragraph 1, Subparagraph 1 of the Act means a male who has not fulfilled his military service obligations and approaching, or of military service age, as defined in Article 3 of the Military Service Act.

“Personal identification document” referred to in Article 5, Paragraph 1, Subparagraph 2 of the Act means an official printout of a ROC household registration record, personal identification card, original ROC household registration record or passport, or other foreign personal identification document sufficient for verification of the applicant’s identity.

“Document of proof of Chinese ethnicity” referred to in the Act means a document of proof of foreign identity that states nationality or ethnicity of the holder as Chinese, or a certificate of Chinese ethnicity issued by the Overseas embassy and consulate, representative office, office or other agency authorized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (hereinafter referred to as “Overseas Missions”).

A person who is issued with an Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate, and who wishes to reapply for such Certificate or apply for an Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement in respect of his/her passport is exempt from producing documents of proof stipulated in Article 5, Paragraph 1, Subparagraphs 4 and 5 of the Act.

Applications for an Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement within ROC pursuant to Article 10, Paragraph 1 of the Act shall be lodged with the competent authority; once the application has been examined and approved by the competent authority evidenced by the issuance of a letter of approval, the application shall be transferred for processing by the Bureau of Consular Affairs (“BOCA”) of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or its delegated authority. An application lodged overseas shall be lodged with an Overseas Mission.

A person holding a valid passport affixed with an Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement may apply to cancel the said Endorsement by completing an application form stating full reasons, and lodging the said application with the BOCA or its delegated authority or an Overseas Mission.

A person holding a valid passport affixed with an Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement who wishes to apply for an Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate is exempt from producing the documents of proof stipulated in Article 5, Paragraph 1, Subparagraphs 2, 4 and 5 of the Act.

Only one Chinese name and one foreign name of the applicant shall be stated on the Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate.
A Chinese name referred to in the preceding paragraph shall not contain aliases, and shall be based on information stated on the applicant’s proof of ROC nationality document or proof of Chinese ethnicity document.
The foreign name referred to in the Paragraph 1 above may contain 1 alias. The foreign name and alias shall be based on information stated on the applicant’s passport or proof of overseas residency document, and shall be recorded in letters of the English alphabet; names not in the English alphabet shall first be translated into letters of the English alphabet.

An application for Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate or Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement under the Act shall be lodged by the applicant in person, or by an authorized representative of the applicant. Where the application is lodged by a representative, such representative shall produce proof of identity document and a power of attorney.
In respect of an application for Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate for non-military service related purposes, where the aforementioned power of attorney is executed overseas, such power of attorney shall be authenticated by an Overseas Mission; where it is executed in ROC, it shall be notarized by a public notary.

Where the form or the documentary requirement of an application for Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate or Overseas Chinese Identity Endorsement under the Act is not fully in conformity with the Act, the competent authority or relevant Overseas Missions shall notify the applicant or his/her representative to remedy the non-conformity within three (3) months of the day following the notice where such non-conformity is capable of being remedied. The application shall be rejected where the non-conformity cannot be remedied.

Where documents required to be submitted under the Act and these Enforcement Rules are in a foreign language, a Chinese translation shall be attached.
Where documents referred to in the preceding paragraph is prepared overseas, such documents shall be authenticated by the relevant Overseas Missions; where the documents are issued within ROC by the ROC embassy or consulate of a foreign country or its authorized representative, such documents shall be authenticated by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
A Chinese translation referred to in Paragraph 1 above shall be notarized by the Overseas Missions or a public notary.
A person who applies for an Overseas Chinese Identity Certificate shall pay the certification fee at the time of collecting the Certificate.
These Enforcement Rules shall commence and enter into force on the date of promulgation.
